p: Obese and obese-diabetic subjects undergo modifications of the innate and adaptive immune response at different phases, characterized by a state of chronic, and low-grade inflammation and a high basal concentration of several pro-inflammatory cytokines such as alpha-TNF, MCP-1, and IL-6, leading to a defect in innate immunity ( 14). Recent evidence indicates that obesity not only increases the risk of infection and of complications for the individual but also increases the chance of appearance of a more virulent viral strain, prolonging virus shedding, and eventually increasing the overall mortality rate of an influenza pandemic ( 15).
